article.title: Emergent Chiral Spin State in the Mott Phase of a Bosonic Kane-Mele-Hubbard Model

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(a) depicts a honeycomb lattice. What do the vectors u1, u2, and u3 represent?
choices: The reciprocal lattice vectors of the honeycomb lattice.
The Bravais lattice vectors of the honeycomb lattice.
Vectors between nearest-neighbor sites on the honeycomb lattice.
The spin orientation of the bosons on the honeycomb lattice.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(b) shows the phase diagram of the BKMH model. What does the central gray region represent?
choices: A region where the B-DMFT method fails to converge.
A ferromagnetically ordered Mott insulator phase.
A region with states that lack coplanar magnetic order.
A phase with long-range superfluid order.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2(a-d) illustrate different spin configurations within the BKMH model. What distinguishes the configuration in 2(b) from the others?
choices: The spins in 2(b) lack coplanar order, while the others exhibit some form of coplanar arrangement.
The spins in 2(b) are all aligned, indicating a ferromagnetic state.
The spins in 2(b) form a 120° spiral order.
The spins in 2(b) are randomly oriented, indicating a paramagnetic state.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2(e) displays the absolute value of magnetization |⟨S⟩| as a function of frustration J2/J1. What is the significance of the fluctuating behavior observed in the CSS phase?
choices: It suggests the presence of long-range magnetic order in the z-direction within the CSS phase.
It indicates a strong response to the staggered magnetic field hz, contrasting with the trivial responses in other phases.
It implies a spontaneous breaking of time-reversal symmetry within the CSS phase.
It reflects the topological nature of the CSS phase.
